quiz.question: Architectural design is primarily concerned with writing detailed code for individual modules.
quiz.suggestion: Review the definition of architectural design as the high-level organization of a system's structure.

quiz.question: Architectural design acts as a critical link between requirements engineering and detailed design.
quiz.suggestion: Recall the role of architectural design in translating requirements into a system structure.

quiz.question: Refactoring the system architecture is usually inexpensive because it only affects a few components.
quiz.suggestion: Consider why architectural refactoring is costly due to its broad impact.

quiz.question: Architecture in the small refers to the architecture of complex enterprise systems distributed across multiple organizations.
quiz.suggestion: Distinguish between 'architecture in the small' (individual programs) and 'architecture in the large' (enterprise systems).

quiz.question: An explicit architecture can facilitate communication among system stakeholders.
quiz.suggestion: Review the benefits of having a documented system architecture.

quiz.question: Simple block diagrams are sufficient to show all semantic details and relationships in an architecture.
quiz.suggestion: Recall the limitations of informal block diagrams.

quiz.question: Architectural patterns are reusable solutions that capture proven design practices.
quiz.suggestion: Review the purpose and nature of architectural patterns.

quiz.question: The Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern is only applicable to desktop applications.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the wide applicability of MVC, including web applications.

quiz.question: A layered architecture organizes the system into a set of layers, each providing a set of services.
quiz.suggestion: Recall the key characteristic of the layered architectural pattern.

quiz.question: In a repository architecture, each subsystem maintains its own database and shares data by passing it explicitly.
quiz.suggestion: Distinguish between repository and explicit data sharing approaches.

quiz.question: Client-server architecture can only be implemented across multiple physical machines.
quiz.suggestion: Recall that client-server can also be implemented on a single computer.

quiz.question: The pipe and filter architectural pattern is well-suited for interactive systems with frequent user inputs.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the typical use cases for pipe and filter architectures.

quiz.question: The '4 + 1' view model includes logical, process, development, and physical views, connected by use cases.
quiz.suggestion: Review the components of the '4 + 1' architectural view model.

quiz.question: Architectural design decisions only affect the functional requirements of a system.
quiz.suggestion: Recall that architectural decisions significantly influence non-functional characteristics.

quiz.question: A key advantage of layered architectures is that changes in one layer only affect adjacent layers.
quiz.suggestion: Review the benefit of separation of concerns in layered architectures.

quiz.question: Architectural Description Languages (ADLs) are widely adopted in industry for documenting system architectures.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the current adoption status of ADLs compared to informal diagrams or UML.

quiz.question: In a client-server architecture, servers can also act as clients to other servers.
quiz.suggestion: Recall that roles in client-server systems can be nested or hybrid.

quiz.question: Performance can be improved in an architecture by minimizing communications and localizing critical operations.
quiz.suggestion: Review how architectural choices impact system performance.

quiz.question: The repository architectural pattern is most efficient when subsystems need to share large amounts of data.
quiz.suggestion: Recall the primary strength of the repository pattern.

quiz.question: Box-and-line diagrams are too abstract to be useful for stakeholder communication.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the practical uses of high-level architectural diagrams.

quiz.question: Architecture reuse across systems in the same domain can lead to the development of product-line architectures.
quiz.suggestion: Review the concept of product-line architectures and domain-specific reuse.

quiz.question: The physical view in the '4 + 1' model shows how the software is decomposed for development teams.
quiz.suggestion: Distinguish between the development view and the physical view.

quiz.question: Safety-critical features should be distributed across many subsystems to reduce risk.
quiz.suggestion: Recall the architectural principle for safety regarding localization of critical features.

quiz.question: In MVC, the View component is responsible for managing application data and business logic.
quiz.suggestion: Review the responsibilities of each component in the MVC pattern.

quiz.question: The pipe and filter model is also known as the batch sequential model when transformations are sequential.
quiz.suggestion: Recall the variant of pipe and filter used in data processing systems.

quiz.question: An architectural model can simultaneously show module decomposition, runtime process interaction, and physical distribution.
quiz.suggestion: Understand that different architectural views are needed to represent different perspectives.

quiz.question: Maintainability is improved by using fine-grain, replaceable components in the architecture.
quiz.suggestion: Review how architectural decisions influence maintainability.

quiz.question: The layered architecture pattern is always the most natural and efficient way to structure any software system.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the limitations and artificiality that can arise with layered structures.

quiz.question: Architectural patterns include information about when they should and should not be used.
quiz.suggestion: Recall that patterns provide context for their applicability.

quiz.question: The output of the architectural design process is a fully implemented and tested software system.
quiz.suggestion: Understand that architectural design produces a model or blueprint, not a complete implementation.
